content.body: Probably not, as most proposals don't have polyfills and the few that do have a disclaimer "do not actually use this polyfill, it's just meant to be an example". However, you can open an issue linking to it so that other people can find it
our repo has an existing polyfill, made by Justin, only for the TC39/JS part of it

Btw Iliasbhal the events handling seems to be wrong, as (if I'm reading the code correctly) you are capturing the context when the .addEventListener call happens rather than when the event is dispatched
content.formatted_body: Btw @iliasbhal:matrix.org the events handling seems to be wrong, as (if I'm reading the code correctly) you are capturing the context when the .addEventListener call happens rather than when the event is dispatched

content.body: Doing it correctly is much more difficult, but it'd would be very great if a polyfill manages to do it!
the semantics of the web integration are explained in https://github.com/tc39/proposal-async-context/blob/master/WEB-INTEGRATION.md

"event is dispatched" means, for example, that if you have a XMLHttpRequest object and you listen to it's "load" event, it gets the context from when you call .send() rather than when you call .addEventListener, since .send() is what eventually causes the event to happen
That was for demonstrating the comparison between SyncContext and AsyncContext. I don't think it is intended for real world use
* That was for demonstrating the idea and comparison between SyncContext and AsyncContext. I don't think it is intended for real world use

m.new_content.body: That was for demonstrating the idea and comparison between SyncContext and AsyncContext. I don't think it is intended for real world use

content.body: nicolo-ribaudo: package updated! The event listener now executes within the same context that when the event was trigered. The event listener can be triggered synchronously or asynchronoulsy it doesn't matter. üëçÔ∏è
